channel.title: Whonix Development News
channel.description:
# Simplified Package Build Process
genmkfile is no longer a build dependency.
genmkfile is now only a tool useful for developers. It provides commands such as `genmkfile manpages` or `genmkfile debinstfile`. See `make help`. It's no longer using a `Makefile` but can be used like any other tool by running `genmkfile` from command line. Therefore most Whonix packages now no longer depend on any other Whonix packages. Therefore getting started with development of any specific package got easier.
See:
* https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Dev/Build_Documentation/security-misc * https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Dev/Build_Documentation/security-misc/easy
# chroot debootstrap install Whonix / Kicksecure to folder
Other Linux distributions such as Qubes and ParrotOS indicated interest in a package developed by Whonix developers, namely [security-misc](https://github.com/Whonix/security-misc), which does Kernel Hardening; Protect Linux User Accounts against Brute Force Attacks; Improve Entropy Collection; Strong Linux User Account Separation; Enhances Misc Security Settings.
* https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/1885 * https://community.parrotlinux.org/t/parrotos-hardening/11649 * https://forums.whonix.org/t/parrotos-whonix/9231
But security-misc is only one component of security hardening. These and other Linux distributions might in future become interested to re-base to [Kicksecure](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Kicksecure), which is a security-hardened, non-anonymous Linux Distribution.
[chroot](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Chroot) / `debootstrap` is a method to download ("install") a Linux distribution in a folder from an already installed operating system. This has [many uses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chroot#Uses) and can be used to build a derivative (of Kicksecure) Linux distribution or Qubes template.
Actually not `debootstrap` but `mmdebstrap` [which is better](https://manpages.debian.org/buster/mmdebstrap/mmdebstrap.1.en.html#DEBOOTSTRAP).
More about Kicksecure:
https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Kicksecure
How to install Kicksecure in a chroot:
https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Kicksecure/chroot
# Continuous Integration (CI)
One test running on Travis CI uses travis.debian.net script (sets up a docker container which runs Debian) where package `whonix-host-xfce-kvm-nonfreedom` gets installed for real.
Another two tests running on Travis CI (one not using apt-cacher-ng, another using apt-cacher-ng) uses `mmbdebstrap` to create a [chroot](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Chroot) for the following meta packages `whonix-host-xfce-kvm-nonfreedom`, `qubes-whonix-gateway`, `qubes-whonix-workstation`, `kicksecure-cli`, `kicksecure-cli-vm`, `kicksecure-xfce`, `kicksecure-xfce-vm`, `non-qubes-whonix-gateway-xfce`, `non-qubes-whonix-workstation-xfce`, which then pull other Whonix packages. Therefore many new build bugs can be quickly spotted.
generally: https://travis-ci.org/github/Whonix/Whonix
a recent successful build: https://travis-ci.org/github/Whonix/Whonix/builds/671191361
# Consolidating Whonix Packages
Progress was made, see: https://forums.whonix.org/t/consolidating-whonix-packages/1945.
# Fix Extraneous Whonix Default Installed Packages Bug
See https://forums.whonix.org/t/whonix-default-packages-review-mmdebstrap-varriant-related-risk-of-regressions/9254.
# Whonix for arm64 / Raspberry Pi ( RPi )
Quote https://forums.whonix.org/t/whonix-for-arm64-raspberry-pi-rpi/1788/153
[quote="Patrick, post:171, topic:723"] Good news. Due to recent development efforts, arm64 / Raspberry Pi (RPi) builds were fixed in Whonix git tag `15.0.1.2.0-developers-only` . [/quote]
> There might still be minor build issues or unrelated issues due to the recent development efforts. Therefore this is likely to work better when the next stable release of Whonix gets released.
> Note: only the build was fixed. I didn’t try to boot the image let alone try it on real hardware. You could help the development if you could create instructions how to boot that image using virtualization such as libvirt configuration files and/or qemu command line to boot the image from a amd64 host.
> It would be good if we had a Debian based CI (continuous integration) server with full support to use `mount` etc. Then Whonix build script could continue to build RPi builds on that server to make sure that new changes don’t break again RPi builds.
# Whonix-Host
Features:
* Debian based, * virtualizer KVM pre-installed * Whonix-Gateway KVM pre-installed * Whonix-Workstation KVM pre-installed * [Kicksecure](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Kicksecure) hardened by default. * Whonix-Host Live ISO * Installable to internal hard drive or external USB. * Whonix-Host Installed version can be booted into Persistent Mode or Live Mode.
Whonix-Host development [progressed](https://forums.whonix.org/tag/whonix-host).
See task list for initial release of Whonix-Host: https://phabricator.whonix.org/maniphest/query/_Obk7yld9FTN/#R
Help welcome!
# Fixing the Desktop Linux Security Model
See also previous Whonix blog post https://forums.whonix.org/t/fixing-the-desktop-linux-security-model/9172.
# Automated Testing
Done:
* https://forums.whonix.org/t/qubes-whonix-using-openqa-instance-by-qubes/8822
In development:
* https://forums.whonix.org/t/automated-test-suite/5942 * https://forums.whonix.org/t/cs-student-capstone-bachelors-senior-project-for-whonix/8821

Kicksecure ™ - Secure by Default

Free, Open Source, Security Hardened Linux Distribution, designed for advanced security, Live or Non-Live (Persistent) Mode.

Kicksecure – 20 May 22

Install Kicksecure ™ inside a folder (chroot)

You can install Kicksecure ™ on top of your existing Debian (based) Linux installation inside a chroot (change root).

Whonix for arm64 / Raspberry Pi ( RPi )

Quote Whonix for arm64 / Raspberry Pi ( RPi ) - duplicate forum topic - #153

Whonix for arm64 / Raspberry Pi (RPi)

Good news. Due to recent development efforts, arm64 / Raspberry Pi (RPi) builds were fixed in Whonix git tag 15.0.1.2.0-developers-only .

There might still be minor build issues or unrelated issues due to the recent development efforts. Therefore this is likely to work better when the next stable release of Whonix gets released.

Note: only the build was fixed. I didn’t try to boot the image let alone try it on real hardware. You could help the development if you could create instructions how to boot that image using virtualization such as libvirt configuration files and/or qemu command line to boot the image from a amd64 host.

It would be good if we had a Debian based CI (continuous integration) server with full support to use mount etc. Then Whonix build script could continue to build RPi builds on that server to make sure that new changes don’t break again RPi builds.
